title: How long will Mass. residents have to wait until their power is restored?
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: Over 100,000 Eastern Massachusetts customers lost power due to Monday's blizzard; restoration efforts continue with significant delays.
Eversource and National Grid work to restore power, with full restoration expected by Wednesday night or Thursday for some.
High winds and difficult storm conditions have challenged power restoration, particularly affecting Cape Cod and the Islands.

title: 15 prospects Patriots fans should know entering the 2026 NFL Combine
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: The New England Patriots have 11 picks in the 2026 NFL Draft, including the 31st overall selection.
Key prospects for the Patriots at the NFL Combine include WR KC Concepcion and edge rusher Zion Young.
Draft targets address specific needs: WR, pass rusher, OT, with names like Kenyon Sadiq and Kadyn Proctor.

title: Malden school employee on leave after alleged ‘serious incident’ involving high school student
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: A Malden school employee is on leave after an alleged incident with a high school student.
The employee, working at Linden STEAM Academy, was placed on leave; no arrests or charges have been made.
Malden police began investigating on February 19; the incident reportedly occurred outside of working hours.

title: These Mass. schools are closed for Wednesday, Feb. 25
author: Audrey Cooney
bullets: Massachusetts schools face closures for a third day after a historic snowstorm dumped up to three feet of snow.
School closures primarily affect districts in the South Coast and South Shore, where the snowfall was heaviest.
Closed districts for Wednesday include Attleboro, Brockton, and Quincy, with some like Canton and Walpole delayed.

title: MBTA to (mostly) resume normal weekday service after historic blizzard
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: The MBTA will resume normal weekday service Wednesday, except for the Fall River/New Bedford line running on a modified schedule.
The Fall River/New Bedford line's reduced service addresses weather impact while ensuring essential workers' travel and ongoing storm cleanup.
Passengers are advised to plan for extra travel time and stay updated via T-Alerts, MBTA Go app, or MBTA social media.

title: Curran: Patriots could ‘explore options’ to potentially upgrade from Stefon Diggs
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: The Patriots face a decision on Stefon Diggs' future with a potential $26.5 million cap hit in 2026.
Tom E. Curran suggests New England might explore options to upgrade or restructure Diggs' contract due to age and cap concerns.
Potential alternatives for the Patriots include signing free agents or trading for a wide receiver, pending Diggs' contract resolution.

title: Mass. representatives, including minority whip, to skip State of the Union address
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: House Minority Whip Katherine Clark and other Massachusetts representatives will skip the State of the Union address.
Ayanna Pressley will spend the day shedding light on detained immigrant children's stories instead of attending the speech.
Ed Markey criticizes Trump's policies and will attend a rally instead of the State of the Union address.

title: Will Charlie McAvoy, Jeremy Swayman be back in Bruins lineup when they resume play Thursday?
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Charlie McAvoy and Jeremy Swayman have been delayed by weather and are uncertain for Thursday's Bruins game.
The Bruins sit in the final Eastern Conference playoff spot, four points ahead of the Columbus Blue Jackets.
Other Bruins Olympic participants, including David Pastrnak, have returned and practiced ahead of Thursday's game.

title: Could Trent Williams suddenly emerge as a free-agent target for Patriots?
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: The Patriots could consider signing Trent Williams if the 49ers release him due to contract disputes.
Williams, 37, has earned five All-Pro nods and 12 Pro Bowl appearances in his career.
Williams' potential release would cost the 49ers a $34 million dead cap hit, staggerable post-June 1.

title: Boston ends snow emergency parking ban; residents can use space savers until Thursday evening
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: Boston lifted its snow emergency and parking ban at 6 p.m. Tuesday after a blizzard left 17 inches of snow.
Residents must remove parked vehicles from discounted garages by 8 p.m. to avoid regular charges.
Space savers must be removed by Thursday 6 p.m., or they will be discarded by the Public Works Department.
